CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 23, 1946, pg. 32, reads: "Mr. and Mrs. Duke C. Finch and Daughter...Learned to live by living. Accompanying article by Elizabeth C. Marshall reads: "Man, 102, Relates How U. S. Grew Up - Duke C. Finch, a slightly-bowed, bespectacled gentleman of 102 years, who resides at 2261Bedford Avenue, Bedford Dwellings, exemplifies the old axiom that 'we lean to live by living.'  The venerable century-old man attributes his longevity to a 'clean, quiet life, prayer and faith - and most of all looking out for the other fellow.' ... Born of slave parents Nov. 7, 1844, in Weldon, N. C., Halifax County, the son of Henry and Charity Finch.  Mr. Finch remained in servitude until the age of sixteen.  Two brothers, Berry and James, and a sister, Jennie, were slaves on the same plantation. - 'Don't Touch Books' - Duke Finch first became aware of the restriction of bondage when he expressed a desire to learn to read and write. His master, William Finch married a school teacher, Miss Brinkley, who kept all the books in mansion under lock and key in the dining hall.  The slaves were not allowed to touch them except when dusting under the eagle-eyed supervision of the mistress.  Under the Finch-Brinkley service the slaves were not permitted to do anything but 'work, hard work' sighed Mr. Finch recalling endless days of unceasing work in the fields of the large plantation .  'Bill Finch was a man though,' Mr. Finch grunted and smiled in remembrance, 'not even his high tempered wife could make him whip the Negroes.' ... he and his 82-year-old wife reside with a daughter, Mrs. Gertrude Jefferson..." image published after event as part of his obituary in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 11, 1952, pg. 1.
TitMainTitle: Gertrude Jefferson, centenarian Duke C. Finch, and Priscilla Finch standing in living room of their home, 2261 Bedford Avenue, Bedford Dwellings, Hill District
